prompt:

@@@ Original Sentence: Yes, I think they can be helpful when the child misbehaves, but they should be used with a little bit of compassion and understanding that it’s not the natural state of things to have an adult yelling at them.  Time outs are also often used without letting the child know how they’re getting out of the time out, which can make it feel arbitrary or like a punishment, rather than a consequence for something they did.  It’s really easy for adults to do this kind of thing unconsciously.  It’s easy to get caught up in the notion that “They’re in time out, and that’s the end of it!” but kids can be pretty imaginative, and they can use their own creativity to make their way out of time outs.  A compassionate time out ends when the child shows a sign of understanding what they’ve done wrong, and are ready to begin again.  That way the child knows they’re learning, and that the parent is seeing them as an intelligent person, even if they sometimes mess up.  You can still use the other techniques you were using to be tough when necessary, but using a compassionate approach will let you use them without actually using them!

@@@ Original Sentence: Sure, Aloo ki Tikki (recipe below). I recommend buying all the ingredients ahead of time. Then you will need to start with step two and have everything chopped and ready by the time you get to step four.

1 onion, finely chopped (5 tablespoons)

5 potatoes (red skinned if possible, they have a sweet taste), cubed

2-3 tomatoes, finely chopped (6-8 tbsp)

1 tsp ginger, grated

1 tsp salt

2-3 cloves of garlic, crushed

1⁄2 tsp red chili powder

2-3 tbsp cumin powder

1 tbsp coriander powder

1 tbsp garam masala

2 tbsp lemon juice

1⁄2 cup (2 oz) coriander, chopped (optional)

Cooking oil

----

Heat cooking oil in a deep pan or kadhai, add the onion, and fry it until it turns light golden.

Remove the onions and drain on a paper towel. Leave the oil in the pan.

Add the tomatoes, ginger, garlic, and salt, stir and cook for about 3 minutes.

Add the chili powder, cumin, coriander, and garam masala. Stir well, and cook for 2 minutes.

Add the potatoes, and cook for 2 minutes.

Turn the heat down, and mix well. Add 2-3 tbsp water, and cook for 8-10 minutes. Keep stirring and checking.

Add the lemon juice. Remove from heat. Mix in the coriander and let it cool a little.

Cut potatoes and tomato and shape into balls.

Heat some cooking oil in a deep pan or kadhai. When the oil is hot, add the potatoes. Fry till they turn light golden brown.

In a paper towel, drain the fried potatoes. Leave the oil in the pan.

In the same oil, add the onion, tomatoes, and fried potatoes.

Stir well, and add 2-3 tbsp water. Cook for 3-4 minutes.

----

In some cases, radiation therapy or chemotherapy may be used as part of the process. Some patients may also have their tumors removed and studied by pathologists. Once the cancer has been identified, surgery is generally recommended, as removing the tumor is the best way to avoid further spread of the cancer. Radiation can be used after surgery to prevent the spread of cancer that may have occurred. Chemotherapy is sometimes used in patients with breast cancer who have a high risk of developing other cancers. Chemotherapy can cause side effects, such as nausea and hair loss, but many patients who receive chemotherapy in the early part of their disease have little or no other symptoms. Since surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy are the most effective treatments for advanced breast cancer, many patients continue to receive these treatments for the rest of their lives.
Question: Are patients with breast cancer referred to a doctor when not experiencing any symptoms? This question is answerable.
